ph_descripcion:
Photos by @ralphpace | A sea otter pup hitches a ride on a larger pup while their mothers feed on a shallow mussel bed in Monterey Bay, California. Mothers will sometimes get together for play dates, which allow pups to release energy while the mothers have time get in some much-needed calories.
(Image taken under U.S. FWS permit #37946D)

A sea otter pup (second slide) searches for food in a giant kelp forest in Monterey Bay. Sea otters will generally dive down the vertical stipe (like a trunk on a terrestrial tree) and look for crabs and snails before they reach the ocean floor. Once there, they'll search for octopuses, clams, and urchins.
(Image taken under U.S. FWS permit #37946D)

In the last frame, a female sea otter pulls mussels from the reef. Although otters can feed on a variety of prey, many tend to specialize in one or two items and will often revisit the same foraging areas over and over. In the case of mussels, it's advantageous to revisit the same cluster because once they break through to the rock it becomes easier to peel off mussels on the edge.

Read the full story at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 24, 2023.

A canine elixir for longevity could lead to one for us: They live in our houses, breathe the same air, and suffer many of the same ailments that affect older people.

Photograph by Becky Hale

ph_descripcion: Photo by @estherhorvath | The Canadian town of Churchill is considered the polar bear capital of the world. In 2017, 18 international artists volunteered their time to paint a series of murals on empty buildings all over town. Some highlighted the local symbol. Please follow @estherhorvath for more polar stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 24, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @rubensalgadoescudero | In Bangladesh, Rohingya children live in makeshift refugee camps adjacent to the border with Myanmar. Following an August 2017 attack by Muslim insurgents, Myanmar’s military began carrying out violent operations against the Rohingya in western Rakhine State, torching whole villages. More than 700,000 of the Muslim ethnic minority fled. Many refugees bring with them stories that have been described by the United Nations as a textbook example of ethnic cleansing. Refugees walked for days with barely any belongings or food, reaching Bangladesh in dangerously overfilled boats. The Rohingya set up camp wherever possible in very difficult terrain and with little access to aid, safe drinking water, food, shelter, or health care. Despite condemnation from the international community, action is still needed to secure justice and protection for the Rohingya. Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens. #Rohingya #Muslim #children #refugee
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 24, 2023. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'I ven'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | Orcas swim through a fjord days before the polar night in the Norwegian Arctic. (A polar night is a winter phenomenon typical of the polar circles when the sun doesn’t rise above the horizon for 24 hours or more, sometimes for months.) In the fall, orcas often move into these fjords, following the migrations of herring from offshore. Throughout the darkness of winter, the orcas will feed on herring, using complex dialects to communicate.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 24, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Hippos violently spar and thrash in the shallows of Kenya's Mara River. A fully grown male can weigh over 9,000 pounds (4,000 kg)—an extraordinary amount to throw around. They're notoriously temperamental and territorial, causing about 500 human casualties in Africa each year. To see more photos from this part of the world, please visit @ladzinski.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 23, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | Today’s custodians of Egypt’s cultural heritage include Mohamed Megahed, who oversees the pyramid complex of Pharaoh Djedkare at Saqqara. In this image, he is looking at the hieroglyphics inside the tomb of Khuwy, a nobleman from the 5th dynasty, at Djedkare’s cemetery in south Saqqara. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 23, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Meet Samba, a two-year-old northern tamandua at the Summit Municipal Park in Gamboa, Panama. This species' anatomy works to its advantage in its forest and scrub habitat, where it spends most of the day sleeping in trees then ventures onto the ground at night in search of food. Tamanduas have a long, prehensile (grasping) tail that can be used as an extra hand or foot while climbing trees. A specialized mouth and tongue allow these guys to consume up to 9,000 ants a day. And the purpose of that thick hair? To protect the tamanduas from being bitten by angry ants as they dine! To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #tamandua #anteater #samba #longtail #bignose #animal #wildlife #animalphotography #wildlifephotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 23, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | Aerial photograph of an Arctic river delta with both dry and water-filled channels in Norway's Adventdalen Valley. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images.
#AdventRiver #Adventdalen #Spitsbergen #Svalbard #Arctic
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 23, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @martinschoeller | Grace Yellow Hammer, Navajo Nation

“The Navajo elders asked me to be their ears, their eyes, and their voice. I was chosen; I didn’t want to. I cried. But that’s what both Navajo traditional elders and Hopi traditional elders told me to do. That’s my job now. So one minute I am over there, one minute I am over here. I went to the United Nations in Geneva to report what was happening to the people 16 times. As long as I am in good health, I will carry the message. That’s all I am: the message carrier."

I thank Grace for her words and time. For more portraits and stories in this series, follow me @martinschoeller.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 22, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Laura Morton @laurakmorton | Fueled by snacks and energy drinks, competitors in a hackathon organized at Hacker Dojo, a Silicon Valley community technology hub, stayed up late into the night working on their projects. I photographed the scene while on assignment for National Geographic to capture the culture of the Silicon Valley. These events, which play an integral role in the tech industry, bring software developers and others together to collaborate intensively on a programming hack over a set period of time. While the focus is unique to each hackathon, the goal is usually the same: to create a piece of functioning software or hardware by the end, often in competition for prizes. For more photographs of people and places, follow along @laurakmorton.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 22, 2023. May be an image of 2 people.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @luisadorr | Daniela Santiváñez, 26, is a member of ImillSkate, a women's skateboarding collective in Cochabamba, Bolivia.

As a child, she was introduced to the skating world by her brother. After she graduated from university, in 2019, she bought her first skateboard and dedicated herself to practicing.

As a nod to the their heritage, the collective performs in traditional pollera skirts, which are mostly associated with Indigenous women from the highlands. "They're considered part of the marginalized population in Bolivia," says Santiváñez, whose great-grandmother wore polleras. The group aims to instill cultural pride and eradicate discrimination.

To read more about the women, check out the January issue, on newsstands now, and read more at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 22, 2023. May be an image of 6 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @babaktafreshi | The National Geographic app opens with this image of the night sky above Utah's Capitol Reef National Park. Designated an International Dark Sky Park, it's indeed one of the darkest places I've visited for nighttime photography. Captured here under the Milky Way and the stars of the Summer Triangle is Capitol Gorge. It's a popular trail by day, but at night you're alone with the striking sounds of nocturnal species. My colleague and I used dim red light during the walk to preserve our night vision and to avoid disturbing animals. That's why in some national parks the light painting technique—using bright light to illuminate landscape at night—is forbidden. It helps keep the night environment natural. Explore more night wonders @babaktafreshi. #stargazing #nightphotography #utah #capitolreef
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 22, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @jasperdoest | “Don’t eat too much,” says Grazia Cosmano, 102, and stick to fruits and vegetables. “Keep it as simple as possible.” That’s how Cosmano became one of an unusual concentration of centenarians in Italy’s Calabria region, says Valter Longo, a biochemist and director of the Longevity Institute at the University of Southern California. Longo, whose parents are from Cosmano’s hometown of Molochio, has known her since childhood. When she turned 100, he added her to his study of Calabria’s centenarians and their diet.

Thank you, Grazia, for your life lessons but, most important, for the joy and laughter.

Read more at the link in bio and follow me @jasperdoest for more images about the science of longevity. #longevity #healthyaging #longevitydiet
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 21, 2023. May be an image of 2 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | A mother sea otter holds her baby in the waters off California. From birth, this young pup will spend most of its life in the sea, only occasionally coming out onshore. That means its fur needs to be kept in tip-top condition. Mum does this at first and grooms her pup meticulously. Sea otters have the warmest fur of any animal, with up to a million hairs per square inch. They rely on it to keep warm, even in the freezing seas of Alaska, but it requires constant grooming. Historically, sea otters came close to extinction throughout much of the range because of fur trapping—their dense warm pelt being highly prized. But strict laws protecting them in the United States has helped rebuild their population. One of the biggest threats that sea otters face in the waters off California these days are great white sharks.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 21, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @tasneemalsultan | Al Balad, Jeddah’s historic center and a UNESCO World Heritage site, premiered a two-day music festival in December called Balad Beast. #jeddah #saudiarabia
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 21, 2023. May be an image of 7 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | I remember as a child that "snow days" were simply unique. It was as if an extra day had been given to us all. I had the same feeling recently when I arose well before dawn to find the African bush blanketed in fog. It wasn't a reason to slip back under the duvet; rather, it was a gift. Imagine for a moment that all that has evolved to predate and to disappear from its prey's view now has the assistance of fog. Then things can get really interesting. To see more follow me @chancellordavid.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 21, 2023.

@natgeotravel

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Farmers harvest coffee cherries in the Manizales region of Colombia. The trees take three to four years before they can bear fruit. The beans are the seeds inside the fruit. The cherries are then harvested, processed, milled, and exported to coffee drinkers around the world.

But the life cycle of the cherries doesn’t stop there. A recent study published in the scientific journal “Ecological Solutions and Evidence” found that the skin, pulp, and other bits of the fruit discarded during the processing stage can be used to fertilize fallow fields. As a Colombian American with ties to this coffee region, I love photographing and visiting the area. For more photographs from Colombia and around the world, follow @sofia_jaramillo5. #coffee #cacao #Colombia
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 20, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Like many of my colleagues, I get often asked, “How do you become a National Geographic photographer?” My answer is often that you don’t “want" to be a National Geographic photographer; you just want to be a photographer who pursues a story like your life depends on it. That story must keep you up at night and make your heart beat faster. If you pursue it and work your craft, good things will invariably come. But it takes time—years. It’s not always easy, and aspiring photographers can be too impatient.

This photograph is from a story I worked on and off for more than 15 years, in Afghanistan’s Wakhan Corridor. It had turned into an obsession, requiring multiple expeditions in every season, learning the language and the landscape, and dealing with stress and joy. The image was taken in 2017 in a high pasture in the Pamir mountains, reachable after a two-week-long expedition. Sidol (at left), Jumagul (center), and Assan Khan were returning on their yaks after monitoring the growth of grasses at lower elevations. Herds would be kept off that pasture so the grasses could be harvested, dried, and used by the Wakhi people for animal fodder in the winter months. I was talking on the satellite phone with my wife on a hill when I saw these beasts climbing up toward me. I had to hang up … and was forgiven!

Read the story at the link in bio. For more insights into our world, please follow @paleyphoto.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 19, 2023. May be an image of 3 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | At Zoo Tampa, an all-female team led by Jaime Vaccaro treats injured and sick manatees—like this one—at the Manatee Critical Care Center, which has three 16,000-gallon medical treatment pools, two underwater pools, and a public observation area. Manatees are a keystone species whose behavior can alert us to environmental and habitat changes that affect our survival. These beautiful creatures are easy to love—attracting adults and kids alike—but recent die-offs show that if we are not alert, they can be gone in the blink of an eye.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 19, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | A goat herder stands for a portrait near the town of Ngiko, just outside of Virunga National Park headquarters in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The park is Africa’s most biodiverse protected area, home to over a thousand mammal, bird, reptile, and amphibian species as well as 1/3 of the world’s endangered mountain gorillas. Virunga is known as the park of fire and ice for its diverse habitats ranging from the Rwenzori peaks to savanna and volcanic plains. Despite its status, Virunga is constantly threatened by war, poaching and other illegal activities, and natural disasters. With the support of donors, the Virunga Foundation actively conserves the park, which spans over 3,000 square miles (7,800 sq km). Over 5 million people reside within a day’s walk of it, many living in extreme poverty and enduring more than 30 years of conflict. The fertile lands in and around Virunga are prime for agricultural exploitation. By preserving the land, many of the world’s poorest are forced to sacrifice opportunity. To tackle this social justice issue, with the support of the EU, Virunga National Park has founded an initiative to foster a locally-led "green" economy based on ecotourism, sustainable agriculture, and energy. Follow me @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 19, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @acacia.johnson | A mother polar bear and two cubs roam the hillside of Kapp Waldburg on Spitsbergen, Norway. Here in the remote Svalbard archipelago, polar bears can be found anywhere, scavenging for food on shore during the summer months when sea ice is less prevalent. These bears were leaving a colony of nesting black-legged kittiwakes, whose eggs could make a snack for the mother and cubs. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from the Arctic and beyond. #svalbard #polarbears #wildlife #arctic
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 18, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @jimmychin | Rock climbers @tommycaldwell and @kjorgeson prepare to battle the Dawn Wall, a route up the sheer face of El Capitan in California's Yosemite National Park.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 18, 2023. May be an image of 2 people.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | After several days of lying in the mud for hours as I tried to photograph shore birds, I was drawn to a group of fiddler crabs. I observed them communicating with a sequence of waves and gestures.

Fiddler crabs are known for their sexually dimorphic claws—the females have two small claws, whereas the male (seen here) has a small and a large one, used to both attract females and threaten other males. The crabs play a key role in the preservation of wetland habitat, aerating the substrate as they burrow in.

The photo was taken in Ecuador, on the shore of a mangrove, with the sun reflecting in the water at sunset. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more amazing creatures. #red #crab #fiddler #fiddlercrab #ecuador
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 18, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Read the full story at the link in bio.

Scientists are just beginning to learn how these common tumors in women are linked to phthalates—chemicals found in hundreds of everyday household items and cosmetics. These chemicals have been linked to uterine fibroids—non-cancerous tumors ranging from the size of a seed to a soccer ball that grow in or around the uterus.

Photograph by Hannah Whitaker, Nat Geo Image Collection
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 17, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'A A common tumor has been linked to chemicals found in hundreds of everyday products'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | A sea turtle is ensnared in discarded fishing net that was drifting in the waters off Sri Lanka. After making this photograph, my team and I freed the turtle, and it strongly and quickly swam away. Mortality from entanglement in plastic, such as discarded fishing gear, has increased substantially over the past century for sea turtles, marine mammals, and birds. #SeaTurtles #OceanPlastic
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 17, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Brendan Hoffman @hoffmanbrendan | A boy plays the accordion for passersby in Kyiv, Ukraine, in late October. After making a few frames, I interrupted him just long enough to ask his name. Damian, he told me. I dropped some coins into his case and moved on, not wanting to disturb his efforts. The response to this image when it was first published, in early November, was overwhelming. I went back to this spot a number of times since. I wanted to learn more about him and let him know that his picture had touched the hearts of people all over the world, but I haven’t seen Damian again. Follow me @hoffmanbrendan for more human stories from Ukraine and elsewhere. #ukraine
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 17, 2023. May be an image of 3 people and text that says '新向 白'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Juvenile brown-throated sloths hug each other during a photo shoot @toucanrescueranch, a wildlife rescue center that raises and then releases dozens of baby sloths each year back into the forests of Costa Rica. Even if they aren’t related, orphaned baby sloths like these two are kept together in pairs to comfort each other after losing their mothers. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #sloths #sloth #babies #hug #orphans #wildlife #animals #hugging #photography #animalphotography #wildlifephotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 16, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @alessandro.cinque | The provinces of Esmeralda and Carchi in Ecuador were once rich in native fauna and flora; now they're increasingly deforested by oil palm monoculture. One of the faces of the resistance to the crop in the region is Doña Julia, 61, from Quinindè. She never wanted to sell her land to the multinational corporations like most of her neighbors, and she's been able to support her family with cacao cultivation on 21 hectares (51 acres) as part of a local farm cooperative.

Doña Julia (above) also founded an organization of women who run a workshop (9th photo) for making chocolate that's sold across Ecuador. She's helped by her husband, Rosendo Evaristo Moran (8th photo), who was injured while working on a palm plantation. Photos two and three show a palm plantation and workers. In photo four, Doña Julia crosses the river to get to her cacao plantation. Two following images detail the cacao process.

To see more of my work, please follow @alessandro.cinque.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 16, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | A couple years ago I captured this image of the moon as it rose above the ancient temple of Poseidon in Cape Sounion, Greece. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #MuhammedMuheisen #Greece #Moon
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 15, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | A nomadic Tuareg poses for a portrait under the Sahara sun. He and a fellow traveler stopped by our camp, a dinosaur excavation site in the remote desert, in search of water. The paleontologists were more than happy to share what they had, and the man allowed me to take his picture. The sword he clasped looked as if it had a history of its own. To see more photos from this expedition, please visit @ladzinski.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 15, 2023. May be an image of 1 person.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @paoloverzone | A polar bear walks across the frozen sea, approaching a passenger cruise ship in Greenland. Polar bears live and breed in the northernmost regions of eastern Greenland. Each year, many bears drift southward with the ice along the coast. Sea ice melts and disappears quickly as the Arctic warms—twice as fast as the rest of the planet. When the sea ice disappears, polar bears have to move onto land, where there are fewer feeding opportunities. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 15, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Ice cones in Austria's Schwarzmooskogel cave used to be 15 stories high. Scientists are now racing to decipher the climate history stored in the ice before it melts into the surrounding pools. The eerie yellow glow seen in this photograph may result from light falling on soil-derived impurities in one ice cone. In "When the Magic Melts," an article in the October 2022 issue, writer Denise Hruby and I document the contributions of both scientists and tour guides as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @shonephoto for more.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 14, 2023. May be an image of 2 people.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beverlyjoubert | The marshes, channels, and deep lagoons of Botswana’s Okavango Delta provide a rich habitat patchwork for so many wild creatures—biodiversity on a scale that's hard to match. Cruising the delta’s winding waterways or basking in the sun along the banks, crocodiles are truly at home here—and top of the food chain. They’re so perfectly evolved for this watery lifestyle that little about these predators has changed for millions of years. And it’s no wonder that many of the delta’s other animal inhabitants approach the water’s edge with a healthy dose of apprehension. #crocodiles #okavango #nilecrocodile #wildlife
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 14, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Rich hues filled the forests of Edinburgh’s Royal Botanic Garden last fall. Sweet chestnuts and the berries of an Arisaema covered the ground. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more photos. #edinburgh #scotland #autumn #plants
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 14, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @jasperdoest | Children born in affluent countries today, such as six-month-old Kiara in southern Italy, will likely live into their 90s, just like Kiara’s great-grandmother Maria Rosa Tranquilla (93). Increased prosperity, better nutrition, and advances in medical science have contributed to a drastic increase in average life expectancy in recent decades.

Although there is no antiaging cure (yet), various scientific insights show that we ourselves can improve the quality of life in old age. While growing older comes naturally, reaching old age is not something to be taken for granted. I believe we should make the most of the life that is given to us. Whatever age I might reach, I hope I’ll sing like Maria Rosa, laugh like Grazia, splash around like Ries, cruise like Aldo, and play like Arnold—to name just a few of the individuals who have welcomed me into their lives during this assignment.

Read the full story at the link in bio and in the January issue of National Geographic. Follow me @jasperdoest for more images about the science of longevity. #longevity #healthyaging #longevityscience
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 13, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Jason Gulley @jason_gulley_science | The millions of gallons of groundwater that gush out of Florida's Homosassa Springs each day maintain a constant temperature of about 74 degrees Fahrenheit (23 degrees Celsius) and create a warm-water refuge for manatees when water temperatures in the nearby Gulf of Mexico plummet. While manatees may look chubby, they have very little body fat and will die from prolonged exposure to water colder than about 68 degrees (20°C). Florida's springs provide natural warm-water habitat that manatees need to survive winter. On cold winter mornings, visitors to the spring inside Ellie Schiller Homosassa Springs Wildlife State Park can expect to see hundreds of manatees gathering to keep warm.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 13, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @kiliiiyuyan | Utqiagvik’s cemetery is the northernmost one in the United States—at the tip of Alaska—and is covered in the deep snow of winter. Fanny Akpik, who recently passed away, was one of the most important elders in the Iñupiaq community here. Standing for a portrait in front of her ancestors, she told me she was responsible for the Iñupiatun language curriculum for the school district, so that generations to come would know their native language. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow me @kiliiiyuyan for more from Arctic Indigenous communities.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 13, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @nicholesobecki | Kenya Wildlife Service veterinarian Wanjala Wavumbah examines Dezmond, an adult male that recently migrated into one of the study’s baboon groups. Researchers estimate that Dezmond is about 12½ years old and his group’s fourth-ranked male. Next, they look at the teeth of the baboon Lyken. As these animals age, their molars’ enamel wears away, which can provide researchers with age estimates. After samples and measurements are taken, the baboons—in this case, Dezmond—are safely released back into the wild. For 50 years, the Amboseli Baboon Research Project in Kenya has studied more than 1,500 baboons across eight generations. What it’s learned could apply to our lives too. Read the full story at the link in bio. To see more of my work on the interdependence of humans and nature, please follow @nicholesobecki.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 12, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Adbul Rahim, 25, holds his sick two-year-old son at a makeshift camp located in a no-man’s-land on the border between Myanmar and Bangladesh. Abdul and his wife walked for 14 days, fleeing the atrocities brought upon his and other Rohingya villages in their home country of Myanmar. Abdul lost his father and all of his belongings when his village was burned to the ground.

Following an August 2017 attack by Muslim insurgents, Myanmar’s military began carrying out violent operations against the Rohingya in western Rakhine State, which resulted in grave crimes under international law, the torching of whole villages, and more than 700,000 of the Muslim ethnic minority group fleeing into Bangladesh. Despite condemnation from the international community, no real action has been done to secure justice and protection for the Rohingya. Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens. #rohingya #muslim #myanmar
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 12, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | Vultures feed on the carcass of a dead zebra on the plains of Tanzania's Serengeti National Park. The vulture's ugly appearance has purpose. The long, powerful necks of these Rüppell's griffon vultures are almost featherless—they have to reach into some pretty horrible places to feed and feathers would be a nuisance. Their bills are curved for tearing flesh and their tongues have backward-facing serrations to grip flesh and bring it into the mouth. Their personalities often confirm their grim demeanor; they're highly aggressive and make a disturbing rasping hiss. But when they're in the air, with wings spread to eight or so feet, they're as perfect a flier as any bird. In fact, the Rüppell's vulture holds the title of highest flying bird after one was once recorded at 37,000 feet (11,000 meters).

I captured this shot with a remote-triggered camera placed inside the carcass. For more on that story, see the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 12, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | I have always been fascinated by what happens to your brain when you go for very long walks. Many of my favorite photo stories have involved walking, often for weeks on end, carrying everything I needed on my back. Here, after a long day’s walk in extreme heat, a pilgrim named Reyaz Husein emerges after taking a dip in a water hole on a pilgrimage route in Pakistan’s Baluchistan Province. Reyaz has done the 180-kilometer-long (112-mile) walk more times than he can recall. For two weeks, I and a few hundred men and women walked under a blistering heat, sleeping at night under the stars and following ancient pilgrimage trails that link holy shrines. For more insights into our world, please follow @paleyphoto. #pilgrims #sufi #sufism
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 11, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | A dust storm at Chaman-i Hazouri park in Kabul, Afghanistan, 2009. This is from a series I titled the Glass House, after I overheard a local refer to the city by that name. He meant that although the capital was somewhat secure with the presence of the American military and its NATO allies, there was still a risk of instability as the country was at war. Indeed, during the summer elections, there were attacks such as car bombs exploding in front of embassies and other public spaces on several occasions. In 2021, after two decades at war with America, the Taliban resumed power. The future of the country hangs in the balance, with 70% of the populace under 25 years of age.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 10, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | Scenes of a white ring stretching up 171 feet and houseboats crowded into what water remains illustrate the sheer amount that's emptied out of Lake Powell as the drought in the American West enters its 23rd year this month. Lake Powell is artificial—and one of thousands in a vast hydrological system that facilitated the rapid growth of cities across the Southwest in the last half century. In these drier times, policymakers and scientists are being forced to rethink our approach to water, our most precious resource that we take for granted. Follow me @elliotstudio as I continue to explore drought stories in the American West.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 09, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | A male-and-female pair of “toothy” Atlantic wolffish inside their den in the waters of the Gulf of Maine. This species is perfectly suited for cold water, as their blood contains natural compounds that prevent it from freezing. Atlantic wolffish are undergoing steep population declines because of overfishing and climate change (warming seawater temperatures), which have already led to local extinction and range contraction. #GulfofMaine #climatechange
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 09, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @erintrieb | When people think of tourism in Mexico, it usually conjures images of ancient pyramids, tranquil beaches, or the vibrant colors of its cities. Few think of mountain climbing. Yet Mexico is home to the highest volcanic summit in North America, Pico de Orizaba (also known as Citlaltépe), at 18,491 feet (5,636 meters)—also the continent's third highest mountain after Denali of Alaska and Mount Logan of Canada.

Only a few hours' drive from Orizaba, Iztaccíhuatl (17,160 feet/5,230 m) is Mexico's third highest peak. Each year both mountains attract locals and foreigners who attempt a summit. Local guiding companies estimate about 2,000 climbers make the attempt each year on Orizaba alone, with an estimated 50% success rate.

Pictured above: A view of Popocatépetl, an active stratovolcano, photographed from the slopes of neighboring Iztaccíhuatl. Other images: Caleb Burns (in red), a guide from SWS Mountain Guides, leads clients up the trail on Iztaccíhuatl for an acclimatization hike. Shortly after midnight on Orizaba, his clients put on extra layers as temperatures drop. Their headlamps light up the glacier on Orizaba, where (last image) a climber nears the summit.

Orizaba’s glaciers shrank 90 percent from 1958 to 2001. Scientists predict the last remaining glaciers in Mexico, located there and on Iztaccíhuatl, will completely disappear within the next 10 years. For more stories on the world's mountains follow @erintrieb.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 09, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @erintrieb | When people think of tourism in Mexico, it usually conjures images of ancient pyramids, tranquil beaches, or the vibrant colors of its cities. Few think of mountain climbing. Yet Mexico is home to the highest volcanic summit in North America, Pico de Orizaba (also known as Citlaltépe), at 18,491 feet (5,636 meters)—also the continent's third highest mountain after Denali of Alaska and Mount Logan of Canada.

Only a few hours' drive from Orizaba, Iztaccíhuatl (17,160 feet/5,230 m) is Mexico's third highest peak. Each year both mountains attract locals and foreigners who attempt a summit. Local guiding companies estimate about 2,000 climbers make the attempt each year on Orizaba alone, with an estimated 50% success rate.

Pictured above: A view of Popocatépetl, an active stratovolcano, photographed from the slopes of neighboring Iztaccíhuatl. Other images: Caleb Burns (in red), a guide from SWS Mountain Guides, leads clients up the trail on Iztaccíhuatl for an acclimatization hike. Shortly after midnight on Orizaba, his clients put on extra layers as temperatures drop. Their headlamps light up the glacier on Orizaba, where (last image) a climber nears the summit.

Orizaba’s glaciers shrank 90 percent from 1958 to 2001. Scientists predict the last remaining glaciers in Mexico, located there and on Iztaccíhuatl, will completely disappear within the next 10 years. For more stories on the world's mountains follow @erintrieb.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 09, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | These caracal kittens were just four weeks old when I photographed them @nashvillezoo. For the first 10 days of life, kittens like these are blind and deaf, making them entirely dependent on mom. Mothers will raise their litter without any help from dad, teaching their kittens everything they need to know before they venture out on their own at nine to 10 months old. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #caracal #kittens #cats #cute #babies #animals #wildlife #mammal #photography #animalphotography #wildlifephotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 08, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Danielle Villasana @davillasana | Running through one of the world’s most biodiverse areas, the Río Dulce flows for 27 miles (43 km) in southern Guatemala before reaching the Caribbean Sea. The area is home to Indigenous communities, including the Afro-Caribbean Garifuna people, along with protected swaths of land and water, such as Río Dulce National Park. Established in 1955, the park has a rich array of flora and fauna—manatees, toucans, crocodiles, and howler monkeys can be spotted here. Follow @davillasana for more photos of communities throughout Latin America.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 08, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | In Norway's Svalbard archipelago, a low sun backlights a radome, which downloads data from weather satellites orbiting the polar regions. The image is part of a series on the unearthly beauty of the Svalbard Satellite Station. For more photos and stories, follow me @reuben.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 08, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Judith Kasiama, who also goes by Juju Milay, poses for a portrait during Roam Fest in Sedona, Arizona, a mountain biking event series for women riders. The portrait is part of an ongoing project I call Women Who Roam, which highlights women of color and those from the LGBTQ+ community who are changing the face of the cycling industry. Kasiama is the founder of @colourthetrails, a collective that advocates for inclusivity in the outdoors.

“Biking is the freedom of mobility without barriers," she says. "Biking is an opportunity to connect with other people. It’s a sense of community, it’s access to transportation, and above all, for me, it brings a lot of joy and childlike wonder.”

Based in Vancouver, Canada, Kasiama noticed barriers to mountain biking when she first began riding. She felt like the marketing by the bike industry promoted only the gnarliest, fastest, and most extreme riding, not the experiences of everyday riders. She also didn’t find anyone who looked like her in the brands’ marketing materials, which ran counter to her experience.

Through her work, Kasiama is helping adults and kids alike break down the barriers to access in the outdoors. “I know we have a long way to go, but for me, I just want more little Black girls doing stuff in the outdoors. To see someone who looks like them in these spaces and hopefully they can have the courage and feel supported in mountain biking or mountaineering or whatever it is.”

For more photographs of women in outdoor sports and cycling, follow @sofia_jaramillo5. #cycling #mountainbiking #womenonbikes
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 08, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @stevewinterphoto | This haul-out of curious walruses swam around our Zodiac for about a half hour in the northeasternmost waters off Svalbard, Norway. We might have been the first humans they’d seen up close. Not long ago these seas were largely inaccessible, frozen in year-round ice.

The Arctic is melting four times as fast as earlier predictions—and I saw the effects everywhere on an expedition to Svalbard in August. The 2022 spring-summer Arctic melt season, when the sun never sets and sea ice retreats, has now ended as the days quickly shorten, with the far north heading back to full winter darkness. It wasn’t record-breaking or news-making for low ice extent—it ranked 10th, tying with 2017 and 2018—but it has been yet another consequential melt season. #arctic #polarbears #walrus
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 07, 2023.

ph_descripcion:

ph_descripcion: Photo by @estherhorvath | Researchers Charlotte Havermans and Marina Ilg deploy a net in Kongsfjorden, in Norway's Svalbard archipelago. Havermans studies polar jellyfish, and in January 2022 she was the first to observe the helmet jellyfish in Arctic waters. The proliferation of jellyfish may be a result of climate change and could affect local fish populations. Jellyfish migrating from warmer waters could compete with native Arctic fish species for the same source in the food web, changing the ecosystem. Please follow @estherhorvath and @awiexpedition for more polar science stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 07, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Pete McBride @pedromcbride | Color, light, and rhythm: they evoke Cuba for me. These unpublished shots are from a decade of National Geographic assignments covering the nation's complex kaleidoscope of culture and politics. I'm grateful to the wonderful friends who helped me there over the years, many of whom I met before the age of cell phones and social media made it easier to stay connected. For more, follow @pedromcbride. #culture #travel #cuba #archive #petemcbride
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 07, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @carltonward | Florida black bears scratch their backs on pines trees @pathofthepanther camera trap sites in South Florida. Trees serve as marking posts where bears leave bite and scratch marks and rub scent from their backs and necks to communicate with other bears in the area. Florida black bears, like the Florida panthers we are looking to document at these sites, are wide-ranging wildlife and need the connected land of the swath known as the Florida Wildlife Corridor to survive. See video of the bears in the "America the Beautiful" series on Disney+ at the link in bio.

To learn more about our work inspiring the protection of the Florida Wildlife Corridor, follow @carltonward. My personal thanks to @bergeronevergladesfoundation. Watch "America the Beautiful" now streaming on Disney+.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 07, 2023.

Many swear by the drug’s ability to ease chronic pain. But experts say the evidence for it is “questionable”—and it may just be the placebo effect.

Photo Illustration by Kurt Mutchler
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 06, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'Some cannabis users swear that it eases chronic pain. ltmaybeallintheirheads. It may be all in their heads.'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @beverlyjoubert | For the hippopotamus, an animal that spends much of its day submerged, the watery landscape of Botswana’s world-famous Okavango Delta is a true haven. But prime real estate in these channels and waterways needs to be defended, especially when water levels drop and these supersize animals are forced to share territory. Hippos have an infamously short fuse, which means aquatic disagreements can quickly escalate from bravado and territorial yawning to physical—and sometimes fatal—clashes. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert. #hippos #wildlife #okavango
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 06, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photos by @kiliiiyuyan | A volcanic ash storm and glacial meltwater pools are signs of major glacial retreat in Iceland, where the first glacier was lost to the effects of climate change, in 2019. As glaciers retreat, fine volcanic glass is uncovered, feeding abrasive winds that strip the paint from vehicles—enough that standard automotive insurance does not cover volcanic ash damage. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan for more on the unusual aspects of a changing climate.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 06, 2023.

Many animals eat their parents, siblings, and offspring for different reasons. The more scientists learn about cannibalism in animals, the more they discover it’s a vital part of nature.

Photograph By Georgette Douwma, Nature Picture Library
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 05, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'Cannibalism among animals is much more common than you think'.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | A German-Egyptian team of researchers led by archaeologist Hourig Sourouzian discovered this head of a limestone sphinx at the archaeological site of the temple of Amenhotep III in Luxor. The mortuary temple was Thebes’s largest funeral complex. Only parts of its design are left, as well as the Colossi of Memnon, two large stone statues measuring 18 meters (59 ft) in height.

Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 05, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @amvitale | Each day, eleven-year-old Irene, pictured with her mother, wakes at 6 a.m. so that she can gather firewood and water and help clean the house before walking three kilometers (2 mi) to her secondary school. She lives in a one-room shack with her parents and two siblings. Access to education has profound impacts on everything from later wage earnings to infant mortality. Learn more, including how to get involved, by following @forthegood and @amivitale. #girls #letgirlsgirlearn #education #school
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 05, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Read the full story at the link in bio.

Amping up the intensity of everyday activities—like charging up the stairs or carrying heavy groceries—can lower the risk of cancer and cardiovascular disease.

Photograph by Solskin, Getty Images
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 04, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'No time to exercise? Just 5 minutes a day has a big impact on your health.'.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @brianskerry | An Atlantic puffin brings back a butterfish to its chick on an island off the coast of Maine. Puffins typically feed their chicks long, slender-bodied fish such as sand lance, whiting, or herring, which the baby puffins can easily swallow. In recent years, the waters of the Gulf of Maine have been warming, resulting in fewer of these commonly found fish species. Puffin parents have had to hunt wide-bodied species like butterfish, which the chicks cannot swallow. Puffin chick mortality will increase as these trends continue. #GulfofMaine #ClimateChange
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 04, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @edkashi | The 2022 World Cup in Qatar exposed the serious issues workers face because of our warming planet. As temperatures rise, particularly in extreme hot zones such as the Gulf states, manual labor performed outdoors is becoming too dangerous. While Qatar implemented some breakthrough solutions—including curtailing working hours during the hottest parts of the day, cooling work areas, and developing “cool suits” for workers—thousands of migrant laborers, who came from places such as Nepal, suffered severe health issues and even death.

This series of photographs was taken in Nepal and Qatar in July and August 2022. (1) A street scene during a nightly Hindu ceremony in the village of Nagrain 9, in the Ghodhas District outside of Janakpur, Nepal. In this village, as with many of the country’s agricultural lowlands, up to 70 percent of its men go to work in Gulf states such as Qatar. (2) At a construction site in Lusail City, Qatar, large fans help workers keep cool. Workers make sure to stay hydrated by drinking lots of water. (3) Rice fields in the hills of Nepal, an area from which tens of thousands of villagers left to find work in countries like Qatar. (4) In downtown Doha, Qatar, buildings under construction rise up alongside billboards promoting the World Cup. (5) Views of the main World Cup stadium in Lusail City. (6) On a construction site in Doha, workers, many from Nepal, line up to leave work at 9 a.m. to rest and avoid the hottest part of the day. (7) Manju Devi Mandal, 38, holds a portrait of her husband, Kripal Mandal, in Nagrain 9 in Nepal. Mandal died at age 40 of a heart attack in Qatar.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 04, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @erikalarsen888 | Blue Springs Park in Central Florida is a winter haven for up to 800 manatees. From the visitor’s walk around the park, tourists can view manatees for hours in this peaceful habitat because in the winter no one is allowed to swim or boat near the springs. This enables manatees to congregate in a quiet environment.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 04, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @williamodaniels | Ndassima gold mine, Central African Republic, 2015. This country’s natural resources are coveted by both rebel groups and foreign powers. They're at the heart of a dynamic that fuels conflict: Wood, gold, and diamonds play a central role in the motivation and financing of militias. In the throes of civil war since 2013, the Central African Republic has been vulnerable ever since gaining independence from France in 1960. Follow me on @williamodaniels for more stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 03, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @acacia.johnson | Pilots fly in formation down the Knik River Valley near Palmer, Alaska. Since the first mail-delivery plane took off in 1924, small aircraft have played a critical role in Alaska’s development. Today, with only 20% of the state accessible by road, nearly all of Alaska is highly dependent on aviation, both for essential transport between remote communities and to access remote wilderness areas. For many pilots, flying is simply a way of life: a way to connect to the landscape and to each other. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond. #alaska #aerial #aviation #airplanes
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 03, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Read the full story at the link in bio.

Antifreeze proteins. Sugar-packed cells. Brain shutdowns. To make it to spring, many species find surprising ways to stop their bodily functions.

Photograph By Janet M. Storey
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 02, 2023. May be an image of text that says 'These animals freeze solid in winter. How do they manage to survive?'.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Austria's University of Innsbruck is one of the main institutions carrying out research to better understand the past, present, and future of European ice caves. Pictured are some of the world’s leading young scientists in this field: Maria Wind, Tanguy Racine, and Gabriella Koltai study maps and reports on ice caves they've sampled. In "When the Magic Melts," my article in the October issue of the magazine, we document the contributions of scientists—and tour guides—as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape. Words by Denise Hruby @denisehruby.

Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @shonephoto for more.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 02, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | Svalbard is located so far north that you need to look south to view the northern lights. Enclosures that house and protect radar antennas, radomes at the Svalbard Satellite Station download data from polar orbiting satellites that monitor climate and improve warnings of potential weather disasters. For more photos and stories, follow me @reuben.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 02, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @luisadorr | Polleras are symbols of cultural identity in Bolivia’s countryside. But the voluminous, traditional skirts worn by Indigenous Aymara and Quechua women have a complex history. Dating to the Spanish conquest in the 16th century, they were imposed by colonial rulers to reflect a style worn in Spain. The skirts eventually were adopted as part of Andean attire, most commonly associated with “cholitas”—Indigenous women from the highlands. Today the skirts, a reminder of rural oppression, are being fashioned as a potent symbol of cultural pride and empowerment by members of ImillaSkate, an all-women skateboarding troupe based in Cochabamba.

Representing strength and fight, polleras carry a legacy of resistance and respect. Twenty-five-year-old Elinor Buitrago Méndez, shown in the pool, says that the beauty of skateboarders wearing polleras sends a powerful message to all women: that they can do whatever they feel like and create a unique way of evolving while at the same time preserving who they are.

Read more about ImillaSkate and how its members are embracing polleras to celebrate their Indigenous roots at the link in bio and in the January issue of National Geographic.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 02, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Photos @stevewinter| Polar bears feed on the two-year-old remains of a whale carcass in Svalbard, Norway.

The Arctic is melting four times as fast as earlier predictions—and I saw the effects everywhere on an expedition to Svalbard in August. The 2022 spring-summer Arctic melt season, when the sun never sets and sea ice retreats, has now ended as the days quickly shorten, with the far north heading back to full winter darkness. It wasn’t a record-breaking or news-making year for low ice extent—it ranked 10th, tying with 2017 and 2018—but it has been yet another consequential melt season. #arctic #polarbears #walrus #Svalbard.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 01, 2023.

ph_descripcion:

ph_descripcion:
Photos by Michaela Skovranova @mishkusk | In Sydney, Robert Cooley grew up on the shores of Gamay (the Indigenous name for Botany Bay) and became a senior Gamay ranger in 2019. The @gamayrangers are the first permanent urban Indigenous ranger group in Australia, providing employment and training as well as opportunities for the rangers to utilize their unique cultural knowledge of the land and sea to care for country and community.

“The goal of the program is to have the ability to influence change in the way the bay is managed," Cooley says. "To have a voice which we have never had before, and ultimately actively participate in land and sea management to help reverse the impact of development."

Today the bay is the city's industrial hub, with a fuel storage facility, the airport, and port “right next to our last remaining patch of mangroves," he says. Industrial development has had a devastating impact on the health of the local ecosystem, cultural sites such as shell middens and rock engravings, and even burial grounds. As the program evolves, the rangers continue to provide crucial environmental and cultural site protection. #Gamay #GamayRangers #BotanyBay #Sydney #Australia
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 01, 2023.

ph_descripcion:

ph_descripcion: Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | Northern fulmar glides over drift ice in the Arctic Ocean. Except for their breeding season, northern fulmars spend their lives on the open seas, flying over large areas in search of food. They catch squid and small fish, among others, near the surface. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images, primarily from the Nordic countries. #Norway #Spitsbergen #driftice #Svalbard #BrashIce #Seaice #ArcticOcean #ArcticSea #AtlanticOcean #Arctic #Northernfulmar #Fulmarusglacialis #Fulmar
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on January 01, 2023.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | The crest atop the palm cockatoo’s head communicates its moods—down when relaxed, up when alert—and so does the color of its featherless cheeks. Normally red, they can turn pink or beige from stress or yellow with excitement. Photo taken @loroparque in Tenerife, one of Spain's Canary Islands. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #cockatoo #bird #female #animal #wildlife #photography #animalphotography #wildlifephotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 31, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @erintrieb | This holiday season, while I spend time with family and friends, going outside to enjoy the freedoms I’ve been gifted simply because of where I was born, my thoughts turn toward the women of Afghanistan.

Last week the Taliban instituted a total ban on the education of girls and women by forbidding them from attending elementary school and universities. Since seizing control of the country in August 2021, the Taliban also has limited their freedom by implementing new laws and restrictions: Women in Afghanistan are forbidden to travel more than 48 miles outside their home without a “mahram,” or a male relative or guardian. They cannot enter government buildings, see a doctor, or take a taxi without being accompanied by a male guardian. In November they were banned from public parks. Most can no longer work at jobs outside the home. Grief-stricken over the loss of their civil rights and personal freedoms, many women are now retreating inside their homes, returning to a way of life reminiscent of Taliban rule in the 1990s.

Pictured here: An Afghan Wakhi woman crouches in reflection at her home in the Wakhan, Badakhshan Province, Afghanistan, 2018.

For more stories on women in Afghanistan follow @erintrieb.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 31, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | Tourists trek the slopes of Mount Etna, in Sicily, one of the world's most active volcanoes. During a six-month period in 2021, when this photograph was taken, Etna erupted enough volcanic material to increase its height by 100 feet (30m).
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 31, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | Egyptian excavators, some with skills and positions passed down for generations, at work at a dig site in the Valley of the Kings, in Luxor. A century ago, Egyptian participation in archaeology was limited mostly to manual labor. However, that began to change when Egypt won independence from Britain and insisted that no artifacts from King Tut’s tomb would be sent to foreign museums or collectors.

Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 31, 2022.

The immediate goal is to create vaccines that destroy cancer cells—but some scientists are also testing vaccines that might prevent someone from developing cancer.

Micrograph by Steve Gschmeissner, Science Photo Library
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 30, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Our National Geographic contributors were tasked with documenting the enduring essence of travel. They opened their apertures on innovative conservation efforts, vibrant cultural communities, and underappreciated destinations. Here are some of our best travel photos of 2022:

📸 @tamaramerino_photography | An ice climber ascends one of the dozens of glaciers in the remote, wind-whipped terrain of Chilean Patagonia. With its ice-carved peaks and fjords, southern Chile remains one of the wildest places on Earth.

📸 @christianziegler | A hummingbird gathers nectar from a cactus flower near Hermosillo, Mexico. In Aztec mythology, the bird represents the sun god Huitzilopochtli, conceived by his mother after she clutched a ball of hummingbird feathers that fell from the sky to her chest.

📸 @aitorlaraphoto | Alba Heredia, a dancer from Granada, Spain, performs at Tablao Flamenco la Carmela in Madrid. Originating in Andalusia about a thousand years ago, flamenco has evolved into a semi-improvised art form of percussive footwork, plaintive singing, and flurries of acoustic guitar.

📸 @putu_sayoga | After a two-year pandemic pause, the Bali Kite Festival returned in August. Hundreds of colorful, fluttering designs, such as this janggan (dragon kite), filled the sky above Mertasari Beach in Bali, Indonesia.

📸 Víctor Zea @victorz3a | In the Peruvian Andes, the ruins of the ancient Inca city of Choquequirao, a cousin to higher profile Machu Picchu, can be reached only by foot or mule. A proposed cable car could make the site more accessible to travelers.

See more of our best travel photos from 2022 at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 30, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @krisgraves | The Living with the Land attraction takes you on a boat ride and greenhouse tour located at EPCOT. The attraction’s Agricultural Sciences team employs innovative growing techniques, including vertical growing systems and aeroponics. The produce is then used at multiple restaurants across the Walt Disney World Resort. The tomato tree was impressive! It's the same variety of tomato as the tree that holds the world record for producing over 32,000 tomatoes! The sample tomato I ate was the best I've ever had.

I was given the opportunity to capture life from behind the scenes at Walt Disney World Resort. Stay tuned for more of what makes Disney possible in the coming weeks and months. The Walt Disney Company is majority owner of National Geographic Partners. @WaltDisneyWorld @DisneyParks @natgeointhefield #DisneyWorld50
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 30, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
For @waynelawrence, one of our Photographers of the Year, portraiture is about capturing a person's essence, which is the most challenging part. “My approach is to always gauge a person’s energy and try to match it," he says. "I’ll know everything is jelling when there is no need to give much direction.”

📸 @waynelawrence | Hlerh Khumalo (at left) and Zwano Mthembu. "One that really touched me is the image I made of a couple in their early 20s, smiling and sitting close together outside a Durban shopping center," he says. "What I like most about their portrait is that I didn’t initially put too much of myself into it and just allowed their joy to bubble to the surface."

📸 Qiniso Dladla @qindladla | While on assignment with Lawrence, photography assistant Qiniso Dladla took a photo of him showing street vendor Ongeziwe Mtate photos he’d taken of her.

Learn more about Lawrence and our other Photographers of the Year at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 29, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Twenty-one wildlife photos were chosen by National Geographic’s photo editors as the favorites of 2022. Here are a few of them.

📸 Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo | A large black bear leaves its den under a vacant home in South Lake Tahoe, California. As bear populations grow and humans expand into formerly undeveloped areas, more of the bruins have been learning to live alongside people—though ultimately city life is not good for these bears.

📸 Karine Aigner @kaigner | Before the coronavirus pandemic, people came to trade, sell, or watch birds at places like this in Havana, where onlookers gathered to watch a songbird take seeds from a handler’s tongue. The demand sparked by these competitions puts wild birds at risk from illegal collectors.

📸 Oliver Meckes and Nicole Ottawa @eyeofscience | Fungal filaments frame a spiky-bodied rotifer, a microscopic animal common in freshwater ecosystems. In soil sampled from Germany’s Black Forest, rotifers propel themselves through the thin films of water that surround plant parts and dirt particles, eating organic debris along the way. This image was taken with a scanning electron microscope, which uses electrons instead of light to capture fine details.

📸 @jasperdoest | A young forest elephant trots along with its parents in Gabon’s Lopé National Park, along one of many paths that generations of the animals have cut through the fruit-rich rainforest.

📸 Jennifer Hayes @jenniferhayesig | After battling to defend the eggs in its nest, an exhausted titan triggerfish lies down in a last attempt to save its young from being eaten by moon wrasses near Anilao, in the northern Philippines.

📸 @sergiomarijuan | A young lynx is photographed by camera trap at an abandoned farm. In 2002 fewer than a hundred of these animals survived in the wild. Since then, the population has grown tenfold, with at least 1,100 animals scattered across Spain and Portugal.

See more of our best wildlife photos from 2022 at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 28, 2022.

📸 Oliver Meckes and Nicole Ottawa @eyeofscience | Fungal filaments frame a spiky-bodied rotifer, a microscopic animal common in freshwater ecosystems. In soil sampled from Germany’s Black Forest, rotifers propel themselves through the thin films of water that surround plant parts and dirt particles, eating organic debris along the way. This image was taken with a scanning electron microscope, which uses electrons instead of light to capture fine details.

📸 @jasperdoest | A young forest elephant trots along with its parents in Gabon’s Lopé National Park, along one of many paths that generations of the animals have cut through the fruit-rich rainforest.

📸 Jennifer Hayes @jenniferhayesig | After battling to defend the eggs in its nest, an exhausted titan triggerfish lies down in a last attempt to save its young from being eaten by moon wrasses near Anilao, in the northern Philippines.

📸 @sergiomarijuan | A young lynx is photographed by camera trap at an abandoned farm. In 2002 fewer than a hundred of these animals survived in the wild. Since then, the population has grown tenfold, with at least 1,100 animals scattered across Spain and Portugal.

See more of our best wildlife photos from 2022 at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 28, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Twenty-one wildlife photos were chosen by National Geographic’s photo editors as the favorites of 2022. Here are a few of them.

📸 Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo | A large black bear leaves its den under a vacant home in South Lake Tahoe, California. As bear populations grow and humans expand into formerly undeveloped areas, more of the bruins have been learning to live alongside people—though ultimately city life is not good for these bears.

📸 Karine Aigner @kaigner | Before the coronavirus pandemic, people came to trade, sell, or watch birds at places like this in Havana, where onlookers gathered to watch a songbird take seeds from a handler’s tongue. The demand sparked by these competitions puts wild birds at risk from illegal collectors.

📸 Oliver Meckes and Nicole Ottawa @eyeofscience | Fungal filaments frame a spiky-bodied rotifer, a microscopic animal common in freshwater ecosystems. In soil sampled from Germany’s Black Forest, rotifers propel themselves through the thin films of water that surround plant parts and dirt particles, eating organic debris along the way. This image was taken with a scanning electron microscope, which uses electrons instead of light to capture fine details.

📸 @jasperdoest | A young forest elephant trots along with its parents in Gabon’s Lopé National Park, along one of many paths that generations of the animals have cut through the fruit-rich rainforest.

📸 Jennifer Hayes @jenniferhayesig | After battling to defend the eggs in its nest, an exhausted titan triggerfish lies down in a last attempt to save its young from being eaten by moon wrasses near Anilao, in the northern Philippines.

📸 @sergiomarijuan | A young lynx is photographed by camera trap at an abandoned farm. In 2002 fewer than a hundred of these animals survived in the wild. Since then, the population has grown tenfold, with at least 1,100 animals scattered across Spain and Portugal.

See more of our best wildlife photos from 2022 at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 28, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Ryley Hausken runs up Mount Adams, in Washington State, as wildfire smoke fills the valley below. This year, the Seattle area recorded the worst city air quality in the world on October 19; air quality consistently deteriorated throughout the summer and fall because of smoke from wildfires—and the problem is getting worse. From 2009-2014, Washington residents were exposed to an average of 22 smoky days per year. From 2016-2020, residents were exposed to an annual average of 34. Climate change increases the wildfire season length, frequency, and burn area. Among the many impacts, it's reducing the ability of adventurers to safely recreate outdoors. For more follow @sofia_jaramillo5. #climatechange #washington #PNW
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 27, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
We sent 132 photographers on assignment. They returned with more than 2.2 million photographs. Here are some of our top pictures of the year.

📸 Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Ali Haider, 19, Najib Khan, 20, and Atif Amin, 24, pose in pumpkin masks trimmed with goat hair during a reenactment of a traditional ceremony tied to glaciers in Pakistan’s Hunza Valley. The ritual was intended to spur new ice flow to irrigate the valley.

📸 Justyna Mielnikiewicz @justmiel | A Lada is enclosed in a glass box at a memorial in Lladoc, Kosovo. The car was carrying Kosovo Liberation Army members Zahir Pajaziti, Edmond Hoxha, and Hakif Zejnullahu when it was ambushed by Serbian forces in 1997.

📸 @hannahreyesmorales | For a peso (less than two cents), neighborhood vending machines bring the internet to Filipinos for a few minutes in Manila. They spend an average of four hours a day on social media, making them some of the world’s most active users.

📸 @arkodatto | Pedestrians, motorcycles, and taxis crowd a street in Mumbai, home to about 21 million people.

📸 @balazsgardi | Rafiullah, 10, packs dirt into a bomb crater on National Highway 1 in Afghanistan's Wardak Province. The 1,400-mile-long ring road has been ruined by decades of war and neglect.

See more from our Pictures of the Year issue at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 27, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @estherhorvath | Scientist Joanna Sulich and others from Polar Bears International prepare to take out the Tundra Buggy One, a mobile research and outreach lab, in Churchill, Manitoba. Sulich, a behavioral ecologist, is studying the impact of climate change on the maternity denning of polar bears. Please follow @estherhorvath for more polar stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 26, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @kiliiiyuyan | The story of sea otters is a complex one, but at least on the central California coast, these oceanic weasels are cherished by the public. Ron Eby is a citizen scientist who has worked tirelessly to restore both sea otters and the Elkhorn Slough area off populous Monterey Bay. Through Eby's concerted efforts together with upstream fruit and dairy farms, the Elkhorn Slough has become vibrant with wildlife, from otters to terns.
Follow me @kiliiiyuyan for more stories of hope between human beings and the natural world.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 26, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Erika Larsen, one of our 2022 Photographers of the Year, embarked on a story about “an almost mythical being—on one hand threatened, on the other, larger than life”: the manatee. Her job was to show the deep connection people have to these ancient animals. “Manatees have become a guide showing me a new, primordial layer of this place where I live. Throughout our work on their story, they acted as mirrors—to those who cross their path, to the places where they live, and to our relationship with the environment that sustains us all.”

📸 Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Fans Topaz Martofel and son Ryder Kramer came from Pennsylvania to attend the Florida Manatee Festival in Crystal River and swim with the docile mammals.

📸 @gena.g.steffens | Erika Larsen hugs a manatee cutout in Bradenton, Florida, while photographing a story about manatees with writer Gena Steffens.

Learn more about Erika and our other Photographers of the Year at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 26, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @tamaramerino_photography | This image of Chilean Patagonia was selected as one of National Geographic's 17 best travel photos of the year. With dramatic peaks, verdant forests, and a swath of ice larger than anywhere but Greenland and Antarctica, it offers travelers one of the last wild frontiers.

About 88% of the country's glaciers can be found in the Northern Patagonian Ice Field. It's one of the world's critical water reserves, and the effects of climate change are visible and dramatic here. The Exploradores Glacier is receding an average of 0.7-0.8 meters (2.2.-2.6 ft) each year. Part of the ice tongue is covered by moraine, an accumulation of debris that comes with glacial movement. Follow me on @tamaramerino_photography for more photos.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 25, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by @joelsartore | Found in rainforests throughout South America, bare-tailed woolly opossums spend most of their time hidden in the dense high canopy, where they nest in tree hollows or in gathered leaves. A nocturnal species, opossums like this one in Florida's @shellfactorynaturepark will move quietly through the trees, feasting on fruit, nectar, tree gum, and arthropods as they explore within their range. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #opossum #baretailed #animal #wildlife #marsupial #animalphotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 25, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | Skaters congregate at the ice rink outside the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #MuhammedMuheisen #Amsterdam #Netherlands
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 25, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @paoloverzone | Today’s custodians of Egypt’s cultural heritage include Mohamed Megahed, who oversees the pyramid complex of Pharaoh Djedkare at Saqqara. The ancient burial ground has been the site of many finds in recent years.

Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 24, 2022.

ph_descripcion: Photos by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | At Colorado’s Rocky Mountain Biological Lab, David Inouye and his granddaughter, Miyoko, carefully trap broad-tailed hummingbirds in order to affix metal identification bands to their legs. The tag is entered into a massive database, which allows scientists to track the migration and behavioral patterns of these remarkable creatures.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 24, 2022.

Believers call him the Son of God. Skeptics dismiss him as legend. Now, researchers digging in the Holy Land are sifting fact from fiction.

Photograph by Simon Norfolk
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 24, 2022. May be an image of text that says 'o Who was the real Jesus? Here's what archaeologists know.'.

ph_descripcion:
We sent 132 photographers on assignment. They returned with more than 2.2 million photographs. Here are some of our top pictures of the year.

📸 @jason_gulley_science | A manatee munches on a wisp of eelgrass in Florida’s Ichetucknee River, whose clean, warm waters can be a winter refuge for the aquatic mammals. Manatees can’t tolerate water colder than 68 degrees Fahrenheit.

📸 @jasperdoest | An elephant gathers the fruit of a Detarium macrocarpum tree off the forest floor in Lopé National Park in Gabon. Research suggests that a decline in Lopé’s tree fruits may be causing forest elephants to starve in one of their last strongholds in Central Africa.

📸 @nicholesobecki | Researchers take samples and measurements from a tranquilized baboon named Olduvai before releasing him unharmed back into the wild in Amboseli National Park in Kenya. Since 1971, scientists have been studying Amboseli’s baboons for clues on aging.

📸 @katieorlinsky | Caribou from the Western Arctic herd gallop across a valley during their spring migration in Alaska’s Kobuk River Valley.

See more from our “Pictures of the Year” issue at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 23, 2022.

Long before a clever marketer turned it into a Christmas staple, the Aztec and Maya celebrated the colorful shrub for its medicinal value.

Photograph by Carrie Thompson, Alamy Stock Photo
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 22, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
How do you photograph the invisible? One of our 2022 Photographers of the Year, Lynn Johnson, faced this challenge while working on a story about human touch—not the act of touching, but the feeling it creates. She couldn’t do that without understanding the importance of it herself. "We can’t sustain this life [as a photojournalist] if it’s not at some level about us," she says. "I think that’s where the powerful work happens, acknowledging that you’re also doing it for yourself."

📸 Lynn Johnson @ljohnphoto | This translucent fabric acts as the skin of an experimental camera-computer combo that “feels” the touch of hands in a novel way—by converting their shadows into information.

📸 Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Photographer Lynn Johnson shares a moment with Morgan Barns, 10, at a playground in Pittsburgh. Johnson has been photographing Morgan and his brother, Max, 12, who are both on the autism spectrum, for 10 years.

Learn more about Lynn Johnson and our other Photographers of the Year at the link in bio.
ph_atributos: Photo by National Geographic on December 22, 2022.
